summary: This is a memorandum opinion and order by Judge Alison J. Nathan denying Ghislaine Maxwell's motion to modify a protective order in her criminal case. Maxwell sought to use discovery materials from the criminal case in certain civil proceedings. The court found she failed to establish good cause and noted much of the information she wanted to disclose was already public or could be sought via unsealing applications in the relevant civil courts.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case who filed a motion to modify the protective order to use discovery materials in civil cases.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge who authored this memorandum opinion and order denying Maxwell's motion.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the subject of a grand jury investigation into him and his possible co-conspirators.

connections.description: The document references a grand jury investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and his possible co-conspirators, with Maxwell being a defendant in a related criminal case.

events.title: Maxwell files sealed motion
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell filed a sealed letter motion seeking to modify the protective order to use criminal discovery in civil cases.

events.title: Protective order entered
events.description: The court entered a protective order in the criminal case, restricting use of discovery to defense of the criminal action.

events.title: Maxwell's reply letter
events.description: Defendant filed a reply letter regarding her motion to modify the protective order.

events.title: Government seeks modification of civil orders
events.description: The Government, ex parte and under seal, sought modification of civil protective orders to permit compliance with grand jury subpoenas.

events.title: Courts rule on modification requests
events.description: One court (Court-1) permitted modification of a civil protective order; another (Court-2) did not.

keyFacts: Judge Alison J. Nathan denied Ghislaine Maxwell's request to modify a protective order to use criminal discovery materials in civil cases, finding she failed to establish good cause.
The motion revealed that grand jury subpoenas were issued to an entity (Recipient) as part of an investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and possible co-conspirators.
The Government had previously sought, ex parte and under seal, modifications to civil protective orders in February 2019 to obtain materials via grand jury subpoenas.
The court permitted Maxwell to provide specific factual information about the grand jury subpoena process to relevant civil courts under seal, as much of it was already public.
The document references an ongoing grand jury investigation, which was a reason cited by the Government for redactions to protect law enforcement proceedings.
